RMP EXECUTIVE SUMMARY
Name of Company:  Ascend Performance Materials, LLC. - Decatur Plant 
Site Address:  1050 Chemstrand Avenue, Decatur, Alabama 35601 
Site Director:  Stephen French
RMP Contact:  Shauna Scott
Phone Number:  256-552-2185

Facility and Regulated Substances:

Solutia's nylon chemical manufacturing facilities were sold June 1, 2009, to form a new chemical company, Ascend Performance Materials, LLC.  Ascend - Decatur Plant is one of the chemical manufacturing facilities that make up the company.  Staffing at Decatur Plant is currently approximately 277 
Ascend employees and approximately 100 permanent resident contractor employees.  Ascend is expanding the production of a primary product, adiponitrile (ADN).  The expansion began in 2017 and will be completed by the end of 2022.  It has been determined that expansion does not affect RMP.

Built in 1952, the Decatur Plant is situated on a 651.82 acre tract (peninsula), 4 miles west of the City of Decatur, on the Tennessee River (river mile 302).  The peninsula is shared by guest operations.  Linde occupies 4 acres, Calpine 20 acres, Toray 50 acres, Styrolution 21 acres.  Over 300 acres are presently in use by Ascend.  The remainder acreage is the old Acrilan footprint which is currently unutilized.

The plant was designed to primarily manufacture Acrilan acrylic fiber and various nylon intermediate chemicals for the production of nylon fiber.  In April of 2005, the production of Acrilan permanently ceased at this site.  The bulk chemicals in the production units and tanks were subsequently removed, with completion occurring by the end of the Third Quarter of 2005.  There are three toxic chemicals in our remaining processes that are regulated by EPA's Risk Management Program (RMP) rule.  The RMP regulated chemicals are:
    	Acrylonitrile (AN) -- A raw material to make nylon intermediate chemicals.    
Propionitrile (PN) -- A co-product from manufacture of nylon Intermediate chemicals.

The main raw material for production of nylon chemicals (i.e., AN) arrives at the plant by barge on the Tennessee River.  AN is fed to an electrohydrodimerization system to produce a mixture of liquid and gas phases.  The organic liquid phase is pumped to raw material recovery and refining processing areas.  AN prestripper columns are used to remove waste from the liquid phase.  Refined ADN is used onsite and shipped offsite.  The co-products of ADN production are ADN flasher tails (AFT), PN, and low boiler make.  All three can be burned on site while AFT and PN can be sold.  ADN gets converted to hexamethylenediamine (HMD) in a two-phase hydrogenation reaction.  Co-products of HMD production are amine heads and bis-hexamethyleneriamine (BHMT).  Both can be sold or burned on site.

Ascend Decatur Plant has officially adopted the following Environmental, Safety, Health and Security Policy and is committed to the success of the program:

** The Plant Manager and the Responsible Care 14001 Management Representative of the Ascend Inc., Decatur Plant are committed to the implementation and maintenance of this Policy.  The commitment includes demonstrating visible leadership and involving the Site Leadership Team and other levels of the organization in the ESSH Management System.

** The Plant Manager and the Responsible Care 14001 Management Representative are committed to openness with internal and external stakeholders.  The ESSH Management System Programs are designed to encourage dialogue regarding the RC 14001 Management System.

** The Plant Manager and the Responsible Care 14001 Management Representative are committed to the continual improvement of our environmental, safety, health, and security performance and our RC 14001 Management System, including prevention of pollution.

** Safety is considered a core value where every person working at Ascend is entitled to a safe, healthy, and secure workplace.  In support of this value, each person working a

t the Decatur Plant is expected to adhere to established policies and procedures and to help identify and eliminate unsafe conditions and at-risk behaviors which can lead to accidents.

** The Plant Manager and the Responsible Care 14001 Management Representative are committed to meet and/or exceed applicable environmental, safety, health, and security regulations, standards and other applicable environmental, safety, health and security requirements, including Responsible Care.

** The Plant Manager and the Responsible Care 14001 Management Representative continually evaluate our operation to establish and pursue objectives and targets to improve the activities, products and services which have a significant impact on the environment, safety, health and security.

** The Plant Manager and the Responsible Care 14001 Management Representative are committed to the Responsible Care Guiding Principles and to continual Responsible Care improvement.

By acting on these commitments, we expect to match the best practices of our peer companies and to adhere to the Responsible Care 14001 guidelines developed by the Chemical Manufacturers Association.

1.0 Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

At the Ascend - Decatur Plant, we are committed to operating and maintaining all of our processes in a safe and responsible manner.  We use a combination of accidental release prevention programs and emergency response planning programs to help ensure the safety of our employees and the public as well as protection of the environment.  This document provides a brief overview of the comprehensive risk management activities that we have designed and implemented, including:

* A description of our facility and use of substances regulated by EPA's RMP rule 
* A summary of results from our assessment of the potential offsite consequences from accidental chemical releases 
* An overview of our accidental release prevention programs 
* A five-year accid

e consequences analyses required under the RMP rule, which implements section 112(r) of the 1990 Clean Air Act Amendments.

EPA's RMP rule requires that we provide information about the worst-case release scenarios and alternative release scenarios for our facility.  The site maintains a list of the scenarios considered, as well as those reported, including information about the key administrative controls and mitigation measures to limit the exposure distances for each scenario.  This information is available at the Decatur site to appropriate inspectors.

For alternative release scenarios (ARS), an evaluation of the most likely system failures was conducted.  This information has been documented, and is available at the Decatur site to appropriate inspectors.

 4.0  General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps

We take a systematic, proactive approach to preventing accidental releases of hazardous chemicals.  Our management systems address each of the key features of successful prevention programs including:

* Process safety information 
* Process hazard analysis 
* Operating procedures 
* Training 
* Mechanical integrity Program 
* Management of change Process 
* Pre-startup review 
* Compliance audits 
* Incident investigation 
* Employee participation 
* Hot work permit 
* Contractors

As part of our prevention efforts, we have implemented the following chemical-specific prevention steps:

  Acrylonitrile (AN) 

*  Tank dike would minimize the release of material.  Check valves on the discharge side of the transfer pumps would prevent material from flowing back into the tank. 
*  An operator would notify the site coordinator immediately.  Cleanup would be handled by the HAZMAT team.
*  Low level alarm on the tank would be triggered.  The area is also visually inspected at least twice daily. 
*  ACAM sensors are located in the units to alarm operations when the detection of AN is present in t

he areas.

  Propionitrile (PN) 

* ACAM system would alarm due to high PN concentration in the air.  The sump level alarm would trigger.  This alarm can only be turned off at a location next to the tank, so someone would have to notice the release while acknowledging the alarm.  Low level alarm on the PNT Tank would go off. The area is inspected at least twice daily. 
*  Tank dike would contain the material and prevent ground contamination.  Check valves on the discharge side of the transfer pumps would prevent material from flowing back into the tank if the release occurred while loading a railcar. 
*  An operator would stop the flow of material into the tank and immediately contact the site coordinator.  Cleanup would be handled by the HAZMAT team.

These individual elements of our prevention program work together to prevent accidental chemical releases.  Our company and our employees are committed to the standard that these management systems set for the way we do business, and we have specific accountabilities and controls to ensure that we are meeting our own high standards for accident prevention.

5.0  Five-year Accident History

On December 31, 2017 at approximately 11:00 PM, a technician was exposed to electrolyte containing AN.  The employee was working on an analyzer and removed a transmitter pad without a proper work permit.  Electrolyte containing AN was released and drained to come in contact with the employees work boot.  The chemical soaked through his work boots and caused 2nd degree chemical burns on his feet.  The employee did not seek immediate medical attention.  A formal root cause analysis investigation followed this event.  The investigation report is available at the Decatur site.

On February 22, 2019, at approximately 16:30, a logistics operator was finishing a Hexamethylenediamine ISO.  He smelled an odor that he thought was Propionitrile and finished sampling the container.  He observed the vent line block valve was open a

nd the cap was not put back on the Propionitrile vent line at an adjacent loading spot.  The operator shut the sampling process down and told his team lead he felt sick.  The operator was taken to the hospital via ambulance by an onsite EMT. At the hospital he received an prescription for nausea and was released.  

6.0  Emergency Response Program
We at the Decatur plant use several types of safety audits to ensure that our plant runs safely.  Following are some of the different types of audits, inspections and reviews that are conducted: PSM and Non-PSM audits, ISO audits, Corporate and Insurance surveys and audits, Environmental and Industrial Hygiene audits, RC 14001 audits, and supervisor audits.  We conduct pre-engineering safety audits and inspections on new process before any engineering work is done.  During the phase of construction walk-through safety inspections are completed.  Pre-startup safety reviews are done before the process is started.

Ascend at Decatur, Alabama is very dedicated in preparation just in case we might have an emergency.  The entire Emergency Response Team receives CPR and First Aid/AED training.  We have approximately 45 firefighters across the 5 shifts that we work.  These firefighters train 48 hours annually at the site on incidents involving flammable liquid fires, interior firefighting, hazardous communications, incident command and others.  Our firefighters receive off-site training at fire schools such as LSU and Texas A&M.  We have two fire trucks on-site.  One fire truck is equipped with foam and another truck is equipped with dry chemical extinguishing agent to supplement the 8 fire pumps that draw fire water from the river.

Currently, we have 9 EMTs training 24 hours annually on trauma assessment, burn care, confined space rescue and others.  The EMT's receive 8 hour CPR and 1st aid training every other year.  On alternating years, the EMT's receive EVOC and EMR training.  We have a fully stocked ambulance readily

available should we need to transport any of our employees to a local hospital.  Our EMTs are all nationally registered and state licensed.

The entire fire brigade is trained to the HAZMAT A&O and technician levels and are pro-board certified and will respond to on-site chemical emergencies.  We also have specialists that respond to on-site and to off-site chemical emergencies.  These dedicated people are trained to handle both railcar and highway emergencies.  They train on chemical data, shipping containers, vessels, tanks and incident command.  We have a fully stocked emergency van that carries supplies that the Specialist use to control any chemical emergencies.

Our site budgets appropriately and provides resources for projects that protect the environment, health and safety of our employees and our surrounding community.  Some examples of projects implemented are maintaining approximately 37 deluge automatic sprinkler systems, 13 smoke detection systems, 7 wet-pipe systems, 8 fire pumps, miles of underground fire mains, hundreds of fire extinguishers, and other protection equipment.

Ascend is a charter member of the Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC) and has a representative on the Executive Steering Committee of this organization.  We are a charter member of the Industrial Emergency Association (IEA) and have a representative on the Emergency Response Committee of the same.  Participation in planning and execution of community drills through our membership in these two organizations has always been rewarding.  Ascend has a good working relationship with other Industrial Plants and emergency responders from the City of Decatur.
There is an on-site emergency response team trained to handle all chemical incidents.  Any chemical incidents that may have off-site impacts are reported to the Morgan County Emergency Management Agency (EMA) which can initiate a county-wide emergency alerting system.  The Ascend-Decatur site also supplies equipment in

emergencies as backup for the EMA's systems.

We maintain an emergency contingency plan, which addresses various federal, state, and local regulatory requirements for emergency response planning.  Our program provides the essential planning and training for effectively protecting workers, the public, and the environment during emergency situations.  Furthermore, we coordinate our plan with the community emergency response plan.

7.0  Planned Changes to Improve Safety

The following is a list of activities that will be continued, or implemented, at the facility to help prevent and/or better respond to accidental chemical releases:

*  Maintain a capital and maintenance program to enhance reliability of operating units, therefore reducing upset conditions. 
*  Maintain OSHA VPP Star Status
*  Maintain ISO 9002 Status 
*  Maintain ISO 14001 Status 
*  Maintain RC 14001 Certification

8.0  Certification

Ascend - Decatur Plant has no Program 1 or 2 processes.
